entries.content: When asked a question, a good salesperson's job is not to give an answer, but to inquire why the question is important or what the true motive is.
Before answering a prospect's question, figure out the reason they asked it.
Do not feel the need to immediately 'vomit up an answer' like a parrot returning a fact when asked a question.
"That's a brilliant question... Do you mind, before I answer that question... because I feel you've asked me for a reason... do you mind sharing with me what that is?"
Prospect asks 'will your system work on Windows?'. Instead of just saying 'yes', ask why they are asking to uncover past failures with other systems.
entries.notes: Illustrates uncovering the root cause (past negative experience) behind a technical question.

entries.content: Be comfortable challenging any question by asking what it means or why it was asked before providing an answer.
Asking 'why' the prospect asked a question helps uncover the underlying reason, potential objection, or past negative experience (the root cause).

focus_area: Objection Discovery: Clarifying questions, isolation, root cause
